EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies 
It is the policy of Shieldalloy Metallurgical to operate worldwide in a manner which protects the Environment, the Health and Safety of our employee and of the citizens of the communities where we have an impact. Excellence in health, safety and environmental protection is essential to our continued success and is, therefor a shared responsibility and a common goal for all Shieldalloy Metallurgical employees.
Our Environmental Health and Safety Policy reaffirms this.


Facility and regulated substances handled
The facility is located in a mostly rural area between the cities of Byesville (to the south) and Cambridge (to the north).  The facility is approximately 1 miles south of Interstate 70 on State Route 209 (Southgate Road) situated directly north of State Route 209.  The property encompasses approximately 245 acres and contains numerous buildings and paved access areas.  Approximately 75 percent of the property is not used for industrial operations and remains undeveloped wetlands and forest.

Two distinct operations occur at the facility, ferrous and non-ferrous metal products, and vanadium chemical production. Metal products include vanadium alloys and co-products include iron-nickel-molybdenum slabs and calcium aluminate slag conditioner (Revan?).  

One raw material used in the manufacture of vanadium alloys is spent petroleum catalyst obtained from hydrotreating, hydrorefining, and hydrocracking refining processes. Hydrotreating and hydrorefining catalysts are regulated as hazardous wastes by EPA; therefor the facility is regulated as a Treatment Storage and Disposal Facility (TSDF).

Chemical production occurs in a separate building located between the main facility and State Route 209. Chemical production consists of the manufacture of vanadium oxytrichloride and vanadium tetrachloride and small quantities of vanadium chemicals such as sodium metavanadate. In the manufactu

re of vanadium oxytrichloride and vanadium tetrachloride, chlorine gas is passed through a reactor with vanadium pentoxide to produce these chemicals. 

The use of chlorine stored in one ton cylinders causes the facility to be subject to OSHA?s (Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations and under the Clean Air Act, EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP). At any given point in time approximately 10 cylinders of chlorine are stored at the facility. Both the worst case and alternative scenarios involve these chlorine cylinders.




Worst-case release scenario
The worst-case release scenario involves a one ton cylinder of chlorine. In an extremely unlikely scenario, the chlorine cylinder is damaged either from falling off of a transport vehicle, a collision of some sort, or a total failure of the cylinder valve mechanism. The entire contents of the cylinder, one ton (2000 pounds) is released in approximately 10 minutes.

The chlorine monitor in this area would immediately alarm, alerting operating personnel of a leak in this area. The existing emergency procedures would be followed to alert the local authorities.

The computer software provided by EPA, RMP*Comp, version 1.07 was used to perform the off-site consequence analysis for the Worst-case release scenario. It assumed a release of the entire contents of one cylinder in ten minutes (200 pounds per hour) It would impact an area 3.0 miles in radius from the chemical plant.



Alternative release scenario
The alternative release scenario involves a release at the feed station, where chlorine from the cylinders is feed into a piping manifold, which transfers chlorine into the reactor vessel. In this scenario this ? inch diameter pipe fails by some mechanical means, resulting in a ? diameter ?hole? by which chlorine would be released. 

The chlorine monitor in this area would immediately alarm, alerting operating personnel of a leak in this area. Personnel would close the cylinder valve thereby stopping the release. The

maximum amount of time to perform this task would be five minutes. The existing emergency procedures would be followed to alert the local authorities.

The computer software provided by EPA, RMP*Comp, version 1.07 was used to perform the off-site consequence analysis for the Alternative release scenario. It calculated a release rate of 112 pounds per minute based on a ? inch hole in the pipe at 150 PSI at 70 degrees Fahrenheit. It would impact an area to 0.5 miles in radius from the chemical plant.


Five-year accident history
No accident at the facility in the past five years has resulted in any release having any off-site impact.








The emergency response plan
The facility maintains as a separate document, an Emergency Notification and Evacuation Plan to address emergency situations that may arise at the facility.


It is the policy of Shieldalloy Metallurgical Corporation to provide a safe and healthy workplace for its employees. We expect our employees to work safely to eliminate accidents and emergencies.  An emergency is defined in this program as a fire, explosion, accident, or a spill or release of a hazardous material, which may result in injury to one or more persons, or result in contamination to the local environment.  In the event of an emergency, all employees will follow the guidelines outlined in this plant notification and evacuation plan.


         David A. Lewis
    Director of Operations

All employees involved in the daily operation and maintenance of the chlorine and vanadium oxytrichloride (VOCl3) and vanadium tetrachloride (VCL4 ) systems should have a full understanding of every operating phase.  This is to include an overview of the process: principles of VOCl3 and VCL4 production, operating characteristics of the components and the associated safety hazards; and the proper steps to be taken to execute all system-related tasks in a safe manner.  Training will be provided, covering the foregoing, to each employee whom, in the normal course of his work, engages in any activities associated with the operation of the chlorine and VOCl3 and VCL4 systems.


SMC CONCEPT OF OPERATIONS FOR EMERGENCIES

1. If an employee discovers an emergency situation, the employee should dial 9-911 to contact the County Dispatcher, and the employee shall notify the supervisor and/or the administrative assistant or replacement.

2. The County Dispatcher will contact the ambulance company for injuries; and contact the fire department or the sheriff for fire, explosion, and/or release of chemical.  On day shift, the administrative assistant or replacement will contact the designated Emergency Coordinator (EC).

3. On day shift, the EC is designated based on the location of incident, e.g., Mill, Roaster or Chemical Plant.  On off-shifts, the production supervisor is to act as the EC until relieved by the appropria

te authority.

4. The EC ? calls for assistance as needed.
For injuries: The EC may assign individual(s) to direct the ambulance to the scene.
For other emergencies: The EC may evacuate the building(s) involved, will account for all scheduled personnel, and assign individual(s) to direct emergency equipment as necessary.

5. The EC may assign trained individual(s) to perform rescue activities, collect environmental samples, man the fire pump, provide additional information, and so on.

6. Emergency notification in the Mill is through a whistle alarm. The Yard Service and Maintenance departments have localized alarms in their respective departments.  The Roaster uses radios to communicate an emergency.  The Chemical Plant uses a red emergency wall switch plus radios.

7. It is estimated that: An ambulance can arrive in 5 to 10 minutes.
 The sheriff can arrive in 5 to 15 minutes.
 The fire department can arrive in 5 to 15 minutes.
